body:
<!--
Thank you for creating a tracking issue!

Tracking issues are for tracking a feature from implementation to stabilization.

Make sure to include the relevant RFC for the feature if it has one.

If the new feature is small, it may be fine to skip the RFC process. In that
case, you can use use `issue = "none"` in your initial implementation PR. The
reviewer will ask you to open a tracking issue if they agree your feature can be
added without an RFC.
-->

Feature gate: `#![feature(checked_sum_product)]`

This is a tracking issue for the `checked_sum` and `checked_product` on Iterators

### Public API

<!--
For most library features, it'd be useful to include a summarized version of the public API.
(E.g. just the public function signatures without their doc comments or implementation.)
-->

```rust
// core::iter

pub trait Iterator {
    fn checked_sum<S>(self) -> Option<S>
    where
        Self: Sized,
        S: CheckedSum<Self::Item>,
    { ... }

    fn checked_product<S>(self) -> Option<S>
    where
        Self: Sized,
        S: CheckedProduct<Self::Item>,
    { ... }
}

pub trait CheckedSum<A = Self>: Sized {
    fn checked_sum<I: Iterator<Item = A>>(iter: I) -> Option<Self>;
}

pub trait CheckedProduct<A = Self>: Sized {
    fn checked_product<I: Iterator<Item = A>>(iter: I) -> Option<Self>;
}


impl CheckedProduct<i8> for i8 { }
impl CheckedProduct<i16> for i16 { }
impl CheckedProduct<i32> for i32 { }
impl CheckedProduct<i64> for i64 { }
impl CheckedProduct<i128> for i128 { }
impl CheckedProduct<isize> for isize { }
impl CheckedProduct<u8> for u8 { }
impl CheckedProduct<u16> for u16 { }
impl CheckedProduct<u32> for u32 { }
impl CheckedProduct<u64> for u64 { }
impl CheckedProduct<u128> for u128 { }
impl CheckedProduct<usize> for usize { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a i8> for i8 { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a i16> for i16 { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a i32> for i32 { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a i64> for i64 { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a i128> for i128 { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a isize> for isize { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a u8> for u8 { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a u16> for u16 { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a u32> for u32 { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a u64> for u64 { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a u128> for u128 { }
impl<'a> CheckedProduct<&'a usize> for usize { }
```

### Steps / History

<!--
For larger features, more steps might be involved.
If the feature is changed later, please add those PRs here as well.
-->

- [ ] Implementation: #95485
- [ ] Final comment period (FCP)
- [ ] Stabilization PR

<!--
Once the feature has gone through a few release cycles and there are no
unresolved questions left, the feature might be ready for stabilization.

If this feature didn't go through the RFC process, a final comment period
(FCP) is always needed before stabilization. This works as follows:

A library API team member can kick off the stabilization process, at which point
the rfcbot will ask all the team members to verify they agree with
stabilization. Once enough members agree and there are no concerns, the final
comment period begins: this issue will be marked as such and will be listed
in the next This Week in Rust newsletter. If no blocking concerns are raised in
that period of 10 days, a stabilzation PR can be opened by anyone.
-->

### Unresolved Questions

<!--
Include any open questions that need to be answered before the feature can be
stabilised. If multiple (unrelated) big questions come up, it can be a good idea
to open a separate issue for each, to make it easier to keep track of the
discussions.

It's useful to link any relevant discussions and conclusions (whether on GitHub,
Zulip, or the internals forum) here.
-->

- What should be done when overflow has occored, but could be recoverd (eg if a `0` is hit in product after overflow, or a negitive number moves the sum back to being in range
- Should `checked_*` take `&mut self`, and leave elements not hit due to overflow
